item.title: Eight file to run for Ward 7 OKC Council seat vacated by Pettis
item.dc:creator: Brett Dickerson
item.description:
At the close of Friday, eight have filed to run for the open Ward 7 Oklahoma City Council seat. The special election non-partisan primary will be Aug. 28. The candidates are: Ed Alexander John Albert Pettis Lisa Butler Leslie Johnson III Chris Harrison Kirk Pankratz Margaret Walsh Nikki Nice If a candidate wins the majority […]

The post Eight file to run for Ward 7 OKC Council seat vacated by Pettis appeared first on Oklahoma City Free Press.

item.title: Bd of adjustment considers Mustang PS, Lifetime Fitness sign proposals
item.dc:creator: Brett Dickerson
item.description:
The entire agenda for the Oklahoma City Board of Adjustment Thursday concerned requests for sign variances. Three applications stood out, one because of the scale of sign variance requested. But, the other two requests for sign variances were significant because of what we learned about the growth of Mustang Public Schools. Mustang Public Schools The […]

The post Bd of adjustment considers Mustang PS, Lifetime Fitness sign proposals appeared first on Oklahoma City Free Press.

item.title: DDRC update – Omni Hotel, The Bower plans approved
item.dc:creator: Brett Dickerson
item.description:
Two projects significant to the rapidly-changing face of downtown Oklahoma City were received by the Downtown Design Review Committee or DDRC Thursday. Omni Hotel The committee reviewed final plans for the Omni Hotel at Oklahoma Boulevard and S. Robinson Avenue next to the new convention center. Both will be east across from the new Scissortail […]

The post DDRC update – Omni Hotel, The Bower plans approved appeared first on Oklahoma City Free Press.

item.title: OKC Council update – neighborhoods receiving new money
item.dc:creator: Brett Dickerson
item.description:
Neighborhood development in core areas of the metro received more attention in the Oklahoma City Council’s first meeting of 2018. Adventure District After a year of hearing complaints from business owners, residents and Ward 7 Council member John Pettis, the council voted to give over $226,000 to actively promote the Adventure District surrounding the OkC […]

The post OKC Council update – neighborhoods receiving new money appeared first on Oklahoma City Free Press.

item.title: OKC Council update – Parking plan for convention center draws questions
item.dc:creator: Brett Dickerson
item.description:
The last big pieces of Oklahoma City’s new Core to Shore project are parking facilities to serve Scissortail Park, the new convention center and convention center hotel. That piece fell into place at the Oklahoma City Council meeting Tuesday. The Central Oklahoma Transportation and Parking Authority report to the council estimated total costs for the […]

The post OKC Council update – Parking plan for convention center draws questions appeared first on Oklahoma City Free Press.

item.title: OKC council update – Small biz, community policing, high-tech parking meters
item.dc:creator: Brett Dickerson
item.description:
Strengthening small business beyond downtown, community policing and a new on-street parking system were among actions taken by the Oklahoma City Council Tuesday. First Loan The Commercial District Revolving Loan Fund made its first loan as of Tuesday’s council vote. A new bakery called “Confections” will open before Valentine’s Day, 2018 as a result. Sarah […]

The post OKC council update – Small biz, community policing, high-tech parking meters appeared first on Oklahoma City Free Press.

item.title: Traffic-calming plan for residential streets moves forward, but who will pay?
item.dc:creator: Brett Dickerson
item.description:
There may be a more substantial answer to speeders terrorizing residential streets by the end of December, but only if each neighborhood can afford to pay for it. The City of Oklahoma City Traffic and Transportation Commission took the next step in developing an Alternative Speed Abatement Program (ASAP) Monday. It involves the city providing […]

The post Traffic-calming plan for residential streets moves forward, but who will pay? appeared first on Oklahoma City Free Press.

item.title: Streetcar update – First car, first loop nearing completion
item.dc:creator: Brett Dickerson
item.description:
The first streetcar is scheduled for delivery in January and the first loop for the streetcar system is scheduled for March 2018 if plans proceed as expected. Wednesday, the Transit/modern streetcar subcommittee of the MAPS 3 Citizens Advisory Board heard reports from representatives of the firm contracted to install and operate the streetcar system and […]

The post Streetcar update – First car, first loop nearing completion appeared first on Oklahoma City Free Press.

item.title: OKC Council modifies panhandling ord, prepares to end color events
item.dc:creator: Brett Dickerson
item.description:
Also hears reports about Streetcar and Draper Lake Trails progress The City of Oklahoma City Council voted unanimously to modify the controversial panhandling ordinance passed December 2015. The changed ordinance allows for activities such as collecting money on medians if the speed limit on the street where the activity is taking place is below 40 […]

The post OKC Council modifies panhandling ord, prepares to end color events appeared first on Oklahoma City Free Press.

item.title: Innovation District gets green light for further dev
item.dc:creator: Brett Dickerson
item.description:
Over the next 21 days planners will be submitting big ideas about what to do next in the Innovation District east of downtown. The district includes the State Capitol grounds and OU Medical Center on NE 13th St. (See map below) The Innovation District was created earlier this year after extensive research by the Brookings […]

The post Innovation District gets green light for further dev appeared first on Oklahoma City Free Press.
